title: Fever
description: A fever is when your body temperature rises above normal (usually over 100.4°F or 38°C). It’s often a sign that your body is fighting an infection.

sections.heading: Common Symptoms
sections.content:
High body temperature (feeling hot to the touch)

Shivering or chills

Sweating

Headache

Body aches

Fatigue (feeling tired or weak)

Loss of appetite

Dehydration (feeling thirsty or dry mouth)

Flushed or pale skin

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
**1) Infections:**

Viral infections (eg, flu, cold, COVID-19)

Bacterial infections (eg, strep throat, pneumonia, urinary tract infection)

Fungal infections

Ear infections


**2) Inflammatory Conditions:**

Rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune diseases

Inflammation due to injury or surgery


**3) Other Causes:**

Heatstroke (overheating)

Medication side effects

Teething (in babies)

Vaccinations (sometimes cause mild fever)

Cancer (rarely)

sections.heading: Precautions & Home Care
sections.content:
Rest: Get plenty of rest to help your body recover.

Stay hydrated: Drink lots of fluids (water, soups, or clear liquids).

Wear light clothes and use a fan to keep cool.

Cool compress: Apply a cool, damp cloth to your forehead, neck, and wrists.

Over-the-counter medications: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen to reduce fever (follow dosage instructions).

Monitor temperature: Keep track of body temperature using a thermometer.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
sections.content:
Fever lasts more than 3 days or gets higher than 103°F (39.4°C).

Severe headache, stiff neck, or rash along with fever.

Difficulty breathing, chest pain, or confusion.

Persistent vomiting or unable to keep fluids down.

Children with a fever higher than 100.4°F (38°C) for newborns, or 102°F (38.9°C) for older children.

sections.heading: Emergency Signs – Go to the ER If:
sections.content:
High fever (above 104°F/40°C) that doesn’t come down with medicine

Severe headache with fever, or stiff neck

Seizures or convulsions

Difficulty breathing

Confusion or delirium

Persistent vomiting or unable to stay hydrated

For infants: any fever in babies under 3 months should be treated as an emergency

sections.heading: Treatment from a Doctor
sections.content:
Blood tests to check for infections or other conditions

Antibiotics (if bacterial infection is present)

Antiviral medications for specific viral infections

IV fluids to treat dehydration if necessary

Antipyretics (medications to lower fever) in case over-the-counter options don’t work

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t ignore a high fever (over 103°F or 39.4°C)

Don’t bundle up under blankets if you have a fever — it can make it worse.

Don’t give aspirin to children under 18 years old due to the risk of Reye’s syndrome.
